thread.section_title: Texas Longhorns News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Carlton: Bitter loss for Longhorns on missed PAT; 'This one here hurts'
thread.title_full: Carlton: Bitter loss for Longhorns on missed PAT; 'This one here hurts' | Dallas Morning News

author: Chuck Carlton
title: Carlton: Bitter loss for Longhorns on missed PAT; 'This one here hurts'
text:
AUSTIN -- One moment, Jerrod Heard was adding another spectacular highlight to a record-setting night and electrifying Royal-Memorial Stadium.
The next, Texas players and coaches were forced to deal with the shock of a missed extra point, an emotional gut punch that left them just short of overtime.
Instead of a potential breakthrough win against a solid California team, the Longhorns were left coping with a bitter 45-44 loss.
"This one here hurts," coach Charlie Strong said. "Extra points are supposed to be automatic."
Strong still expressed pride in the comeback and effort.
"They kept answering and answering and answering," Strong said. "We can learn a lot from this."
Heard engineered a near-miracle comeback from a 45-24 deficit in the fourth quarter. His 527 yards of total offense were the most in Texas history, surpassing the 506 yards of Vince Young. Heard became the first Texas quarterback since Colt McCoy in 2009 against Texas A&M to pass for 300 yards and run for 100 yards.
Heard's 45-yard TD run on a quarterback draw drew Texas within a point with 1:11 to go.
Overtime seemed a formality. Then senior kicker Nick Rose missed wide right on an attempt that may or may not have been deflected, taking the air out of the Texas crowd of 91,568.
"He felt the pressure coming from the outside, and he just mishit it," Strong said.
Rose possesses a remarkably strong leg, as evidenced by a YouTube video of him making an 80-yard field goal this summer in practice. Another showed the kicker equivalent of a trick shot.
Teammates rallied around him.
"We all showed him love," Heard said. "Nick is going to get more critical kicks for us. He can't let that get to his head."
Even the Cal sideline was stunned, although cornerback Darius White said he got a piece of the ball.
"We just assumed after they scored we were going to overtime," Cal coach Sonny Dykes told Fox Sports. "I'm still in a little bit of shock."
D'Onta Foreman's 27-yard run with three minutes remaining had cut the margin to a touchdown. Then Heard took Texas 81 yards in 40 seconds.
Texas outgained prolific Cal (3-0) 650-548 in total yards despite 10 penalties and defensive mistakes.
"Everyone is hurt about this," said safety Kevin Vaccaro, who had nine tackles and forced a key fumble. "We're going to bounce back. We'll learn a lot from this and become closer as a team."
Heard, in his second career start, had a great duel with the Golden Bears' Jared Goff.
Heard finished 20 of 31 passing for 364 yards and added 163 yards on 24 carries and three touchdowns.
Goff, listed in mock drafts as a likely first-round NFL pick, was as good as advertised. He tossed three touchdowns, two to Kenny Lawler, and finished 27 of 37 for 268 yards. Texas lost starting safeties Dylan Haines (targeting ejection) and Jason Hall (shoulder injury) in the first quarter.
Goff didn't have to throw as much as expected. Khalfani Muhammad ran for 164 yards on 10 carries, including a 74-yard touchdown in the third quarter.
Texas has started 1-2 for the third consecutive season. From 2000 to 2012, Texas was 36-3 in its first three games to open the season.
Even with a dynamic young quarterback in Heard and some refocused play-calling by Jay Norvell, there's optimism but also a brutally tough schedule.
With nationally ranked Oklahoma State, TCU and Oklahoma (combined record: 9-0) next on the schedule, Texas could show considerable progress and still be 1-5 or 2-4 at the halfway mark of the regular season.
"I know [Sunday] we'll have a lot of confidence going into the Big 12 season," Heard said.
Follow Chuck Carlton on Twitter at @ChuckCarltonDMN.
